title: Hsinchu County
text:
Hsinchu County (<a href="Wade%E2%80%93Giles">Wade–Giles</a>: "Hsin¹-chu²") is a <a href="County%20%28Taiwan%29">county</a> in north-western <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. The population of the county is mainly <a href="Hakka%20people">Hakka</a>; there is a <a href="Taiwanese%20aboriginal">Taiwanese aboriginal</a> minority in the southeastern part of the county. <a href="Zhubei">Zhubei</a> is the county capital, where the government office and county office is located. A portion of the <a href="Hsinchu%20Science%20Park">Hsinchu Science Park</a> is located in Hsinchu County.
History.
Early history.
Before the arrival of the <a href="Han%20Chinese">Han Chinese</a>, the <a href="Hsinchu">Hsinchu</a> area was home to the <a href="Plains%20indigenous%20peoples">indigenous</a> <a href="Taokas%20people">Taokas</a>, <a href="Saisiyat%20people">Saisiyat</a>, and <a href="Atayal%20people">Atayal</a>. After the <a href="Spanish%20Formosa">Spanish occupied northern Taiwan</a>, <a href="Catholicism%20in%20Taiwan">Catholic missionaries</a> arrived at Tek-kham in 1626. Minnanese (<a href="Hoklo%20people">Hoklo</a>) and <a href="Hakka%20people">Hakka</a> came and began to cultivate the land from the plains near the sea towards the river valleys and hills.
Qing dynasty.
In 1684, <a href="Zhuluo%20County">Zhuluo County</a> was established during <a href="Taiwan%20under%20Qing%20rule">Qing dynasty rule</a> and more Han settled near Tek-kham. A Chinese city was established there in 1711 and renamed Hsinchu in 1875. It became part of <a href="Taipeh%20Prefecture">Taipeh Prefecture</a>. In the late 19th century, Hoklo people dominated the coastal plain area, forcing the Saisiyat and Atayal tribes to move to areas around <a href="Jianshi%2C%20Hsinchu">Jianshi</a> and <a href="Wufeng%2C%20Hsinchu">Wufeng</a>, while the Hakka and Taokas settled together in the river valleys and hills area.
Japanese rule.
<a href="Imperial%20Japan">Japanese</a> <a href="Taiwan%20under%20Japanese%20rule">occupation of Taiwan</a> began after the <a href="First%20Sino-Japanese%20War">First Sino-Japanese War</a> in 1895. Hsinchu became known as "Shinchiku" and, by 1920, <a href="Shinchiku%20Prefecture">its prefecture</a> covered the areas of modern-day Hsinchu County and <a href="Hsinchu">City</a>, <a href="Miaoli%20County">Miaoli</a>, and <a href="Taoyuan%20City">Taoyuan</a>.
Republic of China.
After the <a href="Retrocession%20Day">handover of Taiwan from Japan</a> to the <a href="Republic%20of%20China%20%281912%E2%80%931949%29">Republic of China</a> in 1945, Hsinchu County was established on 25 December 1945. In August 1950, Miaoli and Taoyuan were taken out from the county area to form <a href="Miaoli%20County">Miaoli County</a> and <a href="Taoyuan%2C%20Taiwan">Taoyuan County</a> respectively. On 16 August 1950, <a href="Hsinchu">Hsinchu City</a> was incorporated to the county as <a href="county-administered%20city">county-administered city</a>. However, the city was then upgraded again to become a <a href="Provincial%20city%20%28Taiwan%29">provincial city</a> on 1 July 1982 and was taken out from Hsinchu County area. The county's <a href="Xiangshan%20District%2C%20Hsinchu">Xiangshan Township</a> was incorporated into <a href="Hsinchu">Hsinchu City</a> on 1 July 1982.
Geography.
Hsinchu County is located at the northwest part of Taiwan Island. The county borders <a href="Taoyuan%20City">Taoyuan City</a> to the north, <a href="Miaoli%20County">Miaoli County</a> to the south, the <a href="Taiwan%20Strait">Taiwan Strait</a> to the west, and the <a href="Xueshan">Xueshan</a> & <a href="Dabajian%20Mountain">Dabajian</a> mountains to the east. With an area spanning up to , Hsinchu County is composed mainly of uplands, tablelands, mountains, the alluvial plains of the <a href="Fengshan%20River">Fengshan River</a> and <a href="Touqian%20River">Touqian River</a> mouth area, and some ancient river land.
Climate.
The average climate in Hsinchu County is mild.
Administration.
Hsinchu County controls 1 <a href="county-administered%20city">city</a>, 3 <a href="Township%20%28Taiwan%29">urban townships</a>, 6 <a href="Township%20%28Taiwan%29">rural townships</a> and 2 <a href="Township%20%28Taiwan%29">mountain indigenous townships</a>. <a href="Zhubei">Zhubei City</a> is the seat of Hsinchu County which houses the <a href="Hsinchu%20County%20Government">Hsinchu County Government</a> and <a href="Hsinchu%20County%20Council">Hsinchu County Council</a>. The incumbent Magistrate of Hsinchu County is <a href="Yang%20Wen-ke">Yang Wen-ke</a> of the <a href="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a>. The administrative division of the county are:
Colors indicate the common language status of <a href="Taiwanese%20Hakka">Hakka</a> and <a href="Formosan%20languages">Formosan languages</a> within each division.
Demographics.
The population of the county consists of <a href="Hakka%20people">Hakka</a>, <a href="Hoklo%20people">Hoklo</a>, <a href="Taiwanese%20aborigines">aborigines</a> and new immigrants. The Hakka people constituted around 84% of the total population in 2014, while the aborigines consisted mainly of <a href="Atayal%20people">Atayal</a> and <a href="Saisiyat%20people">Saisiyat people</a>. As of January 2017, the total population was 547,794, with 267,599 females and 280,195 males in 187,644 households.
Economy.
High tech industry.
After the founding of <a href="Hsinchu%20Science%20Park">Hsinchu Science Park</a> in 1980, a high number of high-tech industries began to grow and expand outside the park, attracting workers coming to work and settle in the county.
Education.
Education in Hsinchu County is administered by the Education Department of <a href="Hsinchu%20County%20Government">Hsinchu County Government</a>. The county is home to the <a href="Minghsin%20University%20of%20Science%20and%20Technology">Minghsin University of Science and Technology</a> and <a href="Ta%20Hwa%20University%20of%20Science%20and%20Technology">Ta Hwa University of Science and Technology</a>.
Energy.
Power generations.
Hsinchu County is home to the gas-fired <a href="Hsintao%20Power%20Plant">Hsintao Power Plant</a> with a capacity of 600 MW located in <a href="Guanxi%2C%20Hsinchu">Guanxi Township</a>.
Water supply.
Hsinchu County houses the <a href="Baoshan%20Dam">Baoshan Dam</a> and <a href="Baoshan%20Second%20Dam">Baoshan Second Dam</a>.
Transportation.
Rail.
The <a href="Hsinchu%20HSR%20station">Hsinchu Station</a> of the <a href="Taiwan%20High%20Speed%20Rail">Taiwan High Speed Rail</a> is located in the county at <a href="Zhubei">Zhubei City</a>. Hsinchu County is crossed by three <a href="Taiwan%20Railways%20Administration">Taiwan Railways Administration</a> lines, which are the <a href="Liujia%20line">Liujia Line</a>, <a href="Neiwan%20line">Neiwan Line</a> and <a href="TRA%20Western%20Line">Western Line</a>.
